Institute of Materials Science, University of Connecticut 97 North Eagleville Rd Storrs CT 06269–3136 USA Octahedral molecular sieve (OMS) materials classified by their different tunnel sizes are defined by edge-sharing MnO6 octahedra. Four different OMS materials (OMS-1, OMS-2, OMS-5, and OMS-6) are benchmarked for ethane (C2H6) and cyclohexane (C6H12) oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) and compared with commercial MnO2, M1 phase MoVTeNb oxide, and vanadium oxide (V2O5). The accessibility of the quadrilateral tunnels of the OMS materials to C2H6 and C6H12 were further evaluated using density functional theory (DFT). C2H6 and C6H12 ODH rates for the four OMS materials were higher than those measured for commercial MnO2, MoVTeNbO, and V2O5. The C2H6/C6H12 rate ratios on the four OMS oxides are larger than V2O5. Rate relations for selective accessibility for C2H6 in small pores, accessibility to both molecules in large pores, and the presence of tunnel defects are discussed. Product selectivities show slightly higher ethylene selectivity in smaller pores suggesting possible connections between pore confinement and selectivity. Graphical Abstract Porous octahedral molecular sieves displaying different tunnel structures are prepared to study Oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) reaction using ethane and cyclohexane as substrates. The assessment of the micropore and mesopore pore volumes and compared to the ethane to cyclohexane rate ratios. A relationship in ODH rates and pore sizes and pore volumes was observed, with larger tunnel sizes not being discriminatory to either substrate compared to smaller tunnels that are highly active for ethane and not cyclohexane. Graphic created using Biorender.com ga1 Keywords Pore size Selective Oxidation Manganese Oxide 1 Introduction Oxidation of small alkanes provides essential building blocks for the synthesis of useful chemicals and consumer products [1–4]. Oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) reactions remove hydrogen from organic molecules to form valuable unsaturated compounds. As a result, many studies have pursued efficient catalysts for the ODH of small alkanes and cycloalkanes. Ethene remains one of the most useful and highly produced chemicals in industry due to its versatility as a building block for other chemicals [3]. Industrially, the largest methods of ethene production are steam cracking of large hydrocarbons, ethane cracking, and ethanol dehydration [3,5]. Similarly, cyclohexene is an important building block for aromatics and other cyclic hydrocarbons that can be produced by cyclohexane ODH [6–8]. The ODH process is typically prone to selectivity limitations resulting from product over-oxidation but is resistant to coking for smaller alkanes. Recent studies probed the role of micropores in ethane oxidation rate and selectivity; the studies compared rate ratios of ethane and cyclohexane oxidation over a non-porous supported vanadium oxide and a microporous M1 phase mixed metal oxide [9]. This work illustrated that most of the ethane molecules react within the pores of the microporous oxide [9]. Furthermore, the M1 phase contains channels with an accessible diameter of 4 Å, which enabled the ethane molecules—with a molecular size of 4 Å—to enter and activate within the surface micropores. In comparison, the larger cyclohexane molecules with a kinetic diameter of 6 Å are restricted to activating on the external surfaces [10,11]. The confinement effects of molecules within micropores have been extensively studied for silicious materials based on zeolites. However, the roles of pores for selective oxidations in bulk transition metal oxides remain less extensively probed. Manganese oxide based octahedral molecular sieves (OMS) represent a class of porous materials with one-dimensional tunnels of sizes accessible to small molecules such as ethane. OMS materials have been an area of high interest due to their wide range of tunability for various applications, including capacitors, batteries, heterogeneous catalysts, and gas sensors inter alia [5,12]. The arrangement of the octahedra with an edge or corner-sharing oxygen in these materials leads to the formation of varying tunnel sizes that have been used as hosts for a variety of hydrated cations, including magnesium, sodium, potassium, hydrogen, cesium, and barium, among others [13–17]. These cations allow different oxidation states of vicinal manganese atoms (ranging from + 2 to + 4) by partially balancing the charge of the framework oxoanions [18–21]. The OMS materials are typically prepared via the collapse of a layered structure, birnessite (OL-1), formed at the beginning of the synthetic process [13], which comprises of manganese oxide octahedra, typically with a sodium counter-ion. This paper discusses five major materials: OMS-1, OMS-2, OMS-5, OMS-6, and OMS-7. OMS-1 is a synthetic oxide with a structure similar to the mineral todorokite composed of quadrilateral tunnels with sides containing 3 × 3 MnO6 octahedra [19]. The cation typically found in the tunnel is magnesium (Mg2+), while other cations such as cobalt, nickel, lithium, and copper have also been used [22]. To form OMS-1, an intermediate step exchanging sodium ions of OL-1 with magnesium is performed, which increases the interlayer spacing from 7 Å to 10 Å [21,23,24]. OMS-2 has a structure similar to the mineral cryptomelane composed of tunnels with 2 × 2 octahedra (narrower than OMS-1) and potassium counter ions [16,23]. OMS-5 is a synthetic manganese oxide sieve with a structure similar to RUB-7 composed of tunnels with 2 × 4 octahedra and sodium counter ions [20,25]. RUB-7 is synthesized under strongly basic conditions (pH = 13), leading to a larger sodium hydration radius for large tunnel sizes [20]. OMS-6 is the synthetic form of the mineral romanechite [26], composed of tunnels with 2 × 3 octahedra and sodium counter ions. In addition to these synthesized materials, we also studied a commercial MnO2 sample with the structure of pyrolusite, which is consistent with OMS-7 having 1 × 1 octahedra. These materials show a wide array of morphologies ranging from helices [27,28] to urchin-like structures [29]. and nanorods, among others [24,30,31]. Here, we measure structural and electronic properties of OMS oxides and their reactivity for ethane and cyclohexane oxidation reactions. These data and ethane/cyclohexane rate ratios are compared to previously used vanadium oxide and MoVTeNb oxide. The stability of ethane and cyclohexane molecules inside the tunnels is probed by density functional theory (DFT) calculations to interpret how much the interior sites within OMS tunnels contribute to reactivity, and how such interpretations are influenced by the complexity of the tunnel geometries, morphologies, and electronic properties. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials synthesis All precursors were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. 2.1.1 OMS-1 and OMS-5 These materials were synthesized using a previously published method [32]. Mg(MnO4)2·xH2O was used for OMS-1, and NaMnO4.xH2O was used for OMS-5. These materials were hydrothermally treated for 4–96 h at 513 K. 2.1.2 OMS-2 A previously published method was utilized [33]. A two-solution system was employed. Solution A containing 1.75 mol manganese sulfate with 0.17 mol nitric acid was dissolved in 67.5 mL of deionized water. A secondary solution (Solution B) with 84.2 mmol potassium permanganate in 225 mL of deionized water was prepared. Solution B was added to solution A dropwise and then stirred vigorously under reflux conditions for one day at 373 K. The precipitate was filtered and washed using doubly deionized water to remove any impurities. The resulting filtrate was dried overnight at 393 K. 2.1.3 OMS-6 A previously published method was utilized [20,26]. This synthesis was carried out using a two-step procedure, the formation of a layered manganese dioxide precursor followed by its hydrothermal treatment to form the 2 × 3 tunnel through collapsing of the layers. The layered precursor was synthesized by preparing a solution of 3 M NaOH (12 g NaOH in 100 mL DI water). Once dissolved, 4.4 mmol of KMnO4, this solution was labeled solution A. Solution A was set in an ice bath while solution B was prepared. To prepare solution B, 1.2 mmol of MnCl2·4H2O were dissolved in 125 mL of DI water. Solution B was poured into an addition funnel and added to Solution A dropwise under vigorous stirring in an ice bath. The addition rate was set to 1–2 drops/sec. This was allowed to statically age overnight under stirring. The grey slurry was washed via centrifuge until the pH of the supernatant was neutral. The washed solute was dried at 393 K overnight. The material was grounded using an agate mortar and pestle upon cooling. This material was labeled OL-1. The second part of the procedure was used to convert OL-1 into OMS-6. 0.5 g of OL-1 were dispersed in 14 mL DI water and then stirred vigorously for 24 h. The solution was hydrothermally treated in a 23 mL Teflon-lined autoclave for two days at 503 K. The sample was allowed to cool to room temperature in the oven. The black material that forms at the bottom was broken up and poured into a centrifuge tube. The solution was centrifuged once and then dried overnight in an oven at 393 K. The sample was ground up using an agate mortar and pestle, resulting in OMS-6. 2.2 Catalytic reaction A U-tube quartz reactor was used in which the catalyst samples (0.0531–0.1036 g) were held in vertical fixed beds. Gas-phase reactants (C2H6, 25% in He, O2 25% in He, He 99.999%) were fed using mass flow controllers (Porter). A resistive furnace (National Element), a K-type thermocouple (Omega), and a temperature controller (Watlow) were used to monitor and control temperature. Liquid cyclohexane (C6H12) was evaporated into heated lines using a syringe pump (Cole Parmer). The transfer lines' temperature was maintained at 373 K to prevent condensation of products and reactants. Before introducing the reactants, the catalyst bed was heated to the reaction conditions in helium (30 cm2/min at 5 K/min). The reactor outlet was analyzed using a gas chromatograph (Agilent 7890B). A carboxen-1000 packed column was used to separate CO, CO2, O2, and HCHO. An HP PLOT-Q capillary column was used to separate C2H6, C2H4, and CH3CHO, for C2H6 ODH. An HP1-MS capillary column was used to separate C6H12, C6H10, C6H6, (CH2)4(COOH)2, C6H11OH, C6H10O for C6H12 ODH. O2, CO/CO2, and HCHO were detected using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD), while other products were detected using a flame ionization detector (FID). Reaction rates were reported on a per Mn atom basis for OMS materials and a per V atom basis for MoVTeNbO and V2O5. Selectivities were calculated as percentages of product carbon moles. 2.3 Characterization A Rigaku Ultima IV diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.15406 nm) radiation was used to perform Powder X-Ray Diffraction (XRD) studies between 5 − 75° 2θ (2.0°/min). The resulting patterns were indexed to phases using the Joint Committee on Powder Diffraction Society (JCPDS) database. N2 and CO2 sorption experiments were performed using a Quantachrome NOVA 2000e automated sorption system. All samples were degassed at 393 K for 3 h under vacuum before measurement. The Brunauer−Emmett−Teller (BET) method was used to calculate the surface areas. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) imaging was performed using an FEI Verios 460 L field-emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM) with a Through-the-lens low energy electron detector (TLD). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was performed on an FEI Talos IV microscope. Each sample was dispersed in ethanol and dropped onto carbon-coated copper TEM grids. XPS analysis was carried out on a PHI model Quantum 2000 spectrometer using Al Kα radiation (I = 1486.6 eV) with an ESCA multiprobe (Physical Electronics Industries Inc.) scanning probe. A fixed analyzer transmission mode with pass energies of 187.85 eV and 29.35 eV for recording survey and high-resolution spectra, respectively, were used to record spectra. Binding energies (BE) were measured for Mn 2p and O 1 s. In order to remove sample charging effects, the observed spectra were corrected using the C 1 s BE value of 284.8 eV. CasaXPS software (version 2.3.22) was used to analyze and fit the obtained XPS spectra. X-Ray Fluorescence analysis was carried out using a Rigaku ZSX Primus IV sequential wavelength-dispersive XPF Spectrometer with a 4 kW Rh anode for elemental quantification. 50 mg of sample was placed into a 10 mm sample container. 2.4 DFT calculations DFT calculations were performed using Vienna Ab Initio Simulation Package (VASP 5.4) [34–36]. PBE functionals [37] with D3BJ empirical van der Waals corrections [38] were used. Interactions between atom cores and valence electrons were described by the projector augmented wave method [39]. Convergence criteria of energy changes < 1 × 10-5 eV and atomic forces < 0.05 eV/Å were used for electronic energy calculation and geometry optimization, respectively. Electron occupancies near the Fermi level were described by a Gaussian distribution of width 0.02 eV, and energies were extrapolated to zero width. Spin-polarized calculations were performed with an initial guess of + 3 and − 3 for the magnetic moments of alternate Mn centers, which corresponds to an antiferromagnetic configuration with 3 unpaired electrons at each Mn4+ center. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure analysis X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was conducted to verify the crystal structures of the synthesized oxides. Fig. 1 displays the XRD patterns for OMS-1, OMS-2, OMS-5, and OMS-6. The XRD patterns on commercial MnO2 sample (Sigma Aldrich) and V2O5 catalyst used for comparison with the prepared OMS samples, and the pore structures of OMS samples are shown in Supporting information (Figs. S1 and S2, respectively). The positions of XRD peaks at low 2θ values reflect the size of the unit cells of OMS samples along the sides and diagonals of the tunnel structures. These unit cell dimensions, in turn, determine the sizes of the tunnels after accounting for the space occupied by Mn and O atoms. Table 1 shows the unit cell sizes consistent with XRD data and tunnel shapes and sizes based on distances between O-atoms in opposite ends of tunnels. The XRD pattern for OMS-1 matches the mineral todorokite (Fig. 1, JCPDS card 21–0553; monoclinic, 9.8 Å × 2.8 × 9.6 Å unit cell, β = 94⁰). The peak at 2θ = 12.3⁰ reflects a d-spacing of 7.2 Å, corresponding to the (101) planes with spacing equal to a half of the diagonal of the nearly rhombus-shapes unit cell dimensions perpendicular to the tunnel. The peak near 2θ = 9.4⁰ reflects a d-spacing of 9.4 Å, which is similar to the spacing for (100) and (001) planes along the sides of the unit cell [12]. The diffraction pattern of the OMS-2 sample is consistent with cryptomelane (Fig. 1, JCPDS card 44–0141; tetragonal 9.8 Å × 9.8 × 2.9 Å unit cell).[16,40] For this OMS, the peaks near 2θ = 18⁰ and 2θ = 12.8⁰ reflect d-spacings 4.9 Å and 6.9 Å, which, respectively, correspond to (200) and (110) planes, reflecting half of the length of the sides and diagonals of the square channel. These d-spacings are close to the 4.6 Å and 6.5 Å values previously reported as tunnel sizes for OMS-2. The diffraction pattern for the OMS-5 samples matched with that of synthetic Na 2 × 4 tunnel structure (monoclinic, 14.2 Å × 2.9 × 24.3 Å unit cell includes four tunnels, β = 91.3⁰) as seen by Xia et al. and Shen et al. [20,41], which is based on the Rb-RUB-7 structure reported by Rziha et al. [25]. For this structure, the peaks at 2θ = 7.3⁰ and 2θ = 12.5⁰ represent (200) and (002) planes with spacing equal to a half the length of the long and short edges, 12.1 Å and 7.1 Å, respectively. The structure of OMS-6 is in agreement with that reported for synthetic Romanechite (Fig. 1, JCPDS card 14–0627; monoclinic, 13.9 Å × 2.8 × 9.7 Å unit cell, β = 92.3⁰) [26]. Here, the peak at 2θ = 12.7⁰ reflects a 7.0 Å d-spacing, which corresponds to the (200) planes and reflects half the length of the longer side of the 2 × 3 rectangular channel. The peak at 2θ = 22.8⁰ corresponds to (202) planes with 3.9 Å d-spacing, which is a quarter of the diagonal of the rectangle. The crystal structure of commercial MnO2 (Fig. S1) matches the Pyrolusite mineral, which is consistent with OMS-7. Thus, in the following discussion, we consider this sample as OMS-7. The geometries of OMS tunnels are complex with square, rectangular, or rhombus shapes instead of nearly circular or oval geometries often found in zeolites and M1 phase oxides. The OMS tunnels also exhibit significant corrugations with alternate more and less protruded O-atoms within the tunnels. Therefore, pore sizes cannot be described by a single diameter, and, as a result, we report sizes along one or two different directions. We report a maximum and a minimum size for each direction based on the least and the most protruded O-atom. The pore geometries and the arrows representing distances used to estimate pore sizes are shown in Supporting Information (Fig. S2). Furthermore, the accessible pore sizes are estimated for each case by subtracting two times the ionic radius of O2- anion from the distances between O atom centers. These results are reported in Table 1. The reported dimensions are then used to provide approximate estimates of pore sizes, which further depend on softness of the electron distributions, shapes of molecules that may enter the pores, and flexibility of pore walls. OMS-1 has a nearly rhombus-shaped 3 × 3 tunnel with an accessible size that can allow access to cyclohexane (molecular size ~ 6 Å; minimum tunnel size ~ 6 Å, Table 1). In contrast, the 2 × 2 tunnel of OMS-2 may be accessible or too tight for ethane (molecular size ~ 4 Å; maximum and minimum tunnel size ~4.1 and 2.5 Å, respectively Table 1). The rectangular channels of OMS-5 and OMS-6 are narrow and long, which may allow access to large flat molecules, especially if the walls are flexible to widen around guest molecules along the smaller dimensions. The pores of OMS-7 are inaccessible to any hydrocarbons and even dinitrogen, if no defects creating larger tunnels are present. These details of pores sizes and accessibility to molecules are further probed by assessing the stability of molecules in these pores using density functional theory, as shown later in the discussion. 3.2 Microscopy The morphology of OMS oxides was observed using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). Fig. 2 displays the SEM images for OMS-1, OMS-2, OMS-5, and OMS-6. The OMS-1 sample in Fig. 2a exhibits flaky fibrous spheres. On further examination using TEM, Fig. S3a showed the presence of thin sheets with fibers present as structural supports giving the appearance of fibrous balls, which is consistent with results seen by Vileno et al. [42]. These balls are in the range of 600–700 nm in diameter, with fibers 200–300 nm long. OMS-2 (Fig. 2b) displays an urchin-like morphology with fibers ranging from 700 nm to 3 µm and fiber diameters of 40–80 nm (Fig. S3b). OMS-5 displays larger fibers than OMS-1 and OMS-2 (Fig. 2c). The fibers are observed to be 2–5 µm in length with fiber diameters of 20–50 nm (Fig. S3c). In the case of OMS-6, similar morphology is observed as seen for OMS-1 (Fig. 2d and S3d). 3.3 Surface oxidation state analysis X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) was utilized to study the surface oxidation states of Mn and O atoms. Fig. 3 displays the deconvoluted XPS spectra for Mn 2p and O 1 s using C 1 s (EBinding = 284.8 eV for adventitious carbon) for calibration. The Mn 2p3/2 peak was fitted to 4–5 peaks in agreement with literature, and the adjusted peak positions were calculated ( Table 2) [43–45]. For OMS-1, the adjusted peak position for the Mn 2p3/2 appeared at 643.1 ± 2 eV. OMS-2 with an adjusted peak position for Mn 2p3/2 appears at 642.8 ± 2 eV. OMS-5 with adjusted peak position appears at 642.7 ± 2 eV. OMS-6 with adjusted peak position appears at 642.5 ± 2 eV. In all four cases, the manganese oxidation state is mostly Mn4+. Oxygen 1 s spectra (Fig. 3b) were deconvoluted to three species, surface hydroxyl groups of molecular water (OOH+MW, 531 eV), lattice oxygen (OL, 530 eV), and adsorbed species (OA, 534 eV) [46]. In both OMS-1 and OMS-5, a near 1:1 OOH:OL ratio was observed. In OMS-2 and OMS-6, the ratio was more towards lattice oxygen. The possible rationale behind this is that the magnesium and sodium ions in the tunnels of OMS-1 and OMS-5, respectively, have higher hydration numbers than that of potassium in OMS-2, which may cause an increase in the intensity of the molecular water peak. In OMS-6, the O 1 s transition also shows the presence of OA, indicating the presence of possible adsorbed species. The OMS tunnels are partially occupied by Na+, Mg2+, or K+ cations. X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy revealed that Mg:Mn ratio in OMS-1 is 1:6 while the Na:Mn ratio in OMS-5 is 1:6.3. These values are smaller than the ~1:3 Mg:Mn and 2:3 Na:Mn ratios in stoichiometric OMS-1 and OMS-5 oxides, respectively. This suggests possible micropore accessibility resulting from partial vacancies of cations within the tunnels. The accessible micropore volumes and the mesoporous surface areas due to the outer surfaces of the sheets and fibers observed in micrographs were studied using N2 and CO2 sorption isotherms ( Fig. 4). The CO2 sorption isotherms on OMS samples exhibit hysteresis loops in the micropore filling, as shown for OMS-1, OMS-2, OMS-5, OMS-6, and OMS-7 in the Supporting information (Fig. S4), and shown previously for OMS-2 [47]. 3.4 Pore size analysis Both N2 and CO2 isotherms show small uptakes at very small relative pressures (Fig. 4a, b, P/P0 values < 0.002; P0 = saturation pressure at the measurement temperature: 1 atm for N2 at 77 K and 64 atm for CO2 at 298 K), which is indicative of micropores in these samples. The OMS-1 sample shows uptakes of 27 and 10 cm3/g at P/P0 values near 0.002 for N2 and CO2, respectively. The CO2 uptakes are about two to three-fold smaller than N2, but both gases show similar trends for the type of OMS (Fig. 4c). For both probe gas molecules, the uptake values are similar on OMS-2, OMS-5, and OMS-6 samples, suggesting that these samples have similar amounts of micropores that are about half the micropore volumes in the OMS-1 sample. OMS-7 exhibits a much lower gas uptake than the other OMS samples, consistent with essentially inaccessible pores. The small quantities of pores measured are likely to arise from defects creating tunnels from rows of missing MnO2 units. The CO2 uptakes for measurements with decreasing CO2 pressures are slightly larger than the increasing pressure (Fig. 3c) due to the hysteresis loop behavior shown in Fig. S4. These gas uptakes and pore volumes estimated from the liquid phase density of N2 and CO2 are shown in Table 3. The changes in N2 uptakes near 0.05–0.35 P/P0 values are analyzed using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) theory to estimate the mesoporous and macroporous surface area in the OMS samples. Table 3 also displays these BET surface areas of the different materials. Previous BET surface areas reported in the literature range from 50 to 200 m2/g, consistent with the results obtained in this study for OMS-1, OMS-2, OMS-5, and OMS-6 [12]. The OMS-1 sample exhibits the highest surface area (164 cm3/g). On the other hand, the OMS-7 (commercial MnO2) sample exhibits the lowest surface area of all samples in Table 3 (3.7 cm3/g), suggesting large crystallites with few surfaces. The difference between N2 uptakes with increasing and decreasing pressures represents a hysteresis loop caused by the aggregation of adsorbate and the presence of internal voids [48]. The hysteresis loop is much more significant for the OMS-1 than the other OMS samples, suggesting that this sample has more internal mesopores than the other OMS samples. Table 3 also shows micropore volume to external BET surface area ratios as a measure of quantities of internal to external surface catalytic sites and compares OMS samples with V2O5 and MoVTeNbO catalysts previously studied. These ratios are the smallest for V2O5 samples (2.7 ×10-9 cm). On the other hand, the OMS and MoVTeNbO samples exhibit larger ratios consistent with more micropores relative to outer surfaces (0.7 ×10-8 to 6.4 ×10-8 cm). 3.5 Ethane and Cyclohexane ODH These material characterizations show that OMS materials exhibit expected crystal structures and lattice dimensions, morphologies, and oxidation states of ions. We also show that the samples exhibit varying degrees of micropore accessibility to CO2 and N2, external surface areas, and pore shapes and sizes. The variations in pore shapes and sizes make the accessibility highly molecule dependent. Therefore, we next probe reactivity for the oxidation of two molecules, ethane and cyclohexane, with the latter molecule being larger (4 Å vs. 6 Å). The reactions can occur within internal accessible micropores or on the outer surfaces of the nanorods. As a result, the total reaction rate for a given molecule ( r reaction ) represent the sum of the intrapore rate ( r pore ) and the rate on outer surfaces ( r surface ): (1) r reaction = r pore + r surface Ethane has a smaller size, which suggests that pore sizes in between ethane and cyclohexane can allow selective access to ethane. In this case, ethane rates would have greater pore contributions. However, larger pores can allow access to both molecules and even selectively stabilize larger molecules via van der Waals stabilization due to a better fit in the pores. These details are probed next by reaction rates for both molecules (ethane at 648 K and cyclohexane at 523 K, due to the higher intrinsic reactivity of a cyclohexane molecule with weaker C-H bonds), their ratios, and how they trend with micropore volume to BET area ratios, as shown in Fig. 5. The ethane oxidation rate is the highest on the OMS-1 sample, followed by OMS-6 and OMS-5 (32 × 10-5, 27 × 10-5, 23 × 10-5 molecules Mn-1 s-1, respectively, Fig. 5a), consistent with the trends in both pore volumes and BET areas in these samples in Table 3. OMS-2 has a smaller rate (17 × 10-5 molecules Mn-1 s-1) despite larger BET areas than OMS-5 but is consistent with smaller micropore volume. OMS-7 (commercial MnO2) exhibits the lowest C2H6 oxidation rates of all OMS samples (4.8 × 10-5 molecules Mn-1 s-1), also consistent with small micropore volumes and BET areas. This rate is about seven-fold lower than OMS-1. The rate on the V2O5 sample (0.1 × 10-5 molecules V-1 s-1) is even lower than OMS-7, suggesting low intrinsic reactivity of vanadium oxides compared to manganese oxides. However, the MoVTeNbO sample has a higher rate (8.5 × 10-5 molecules V-1 s-1) due to pore accessibility, as shown previously [9]. The cyclohexane oxidation rate is the highest for OMS-1, OMS-5, and OMS-6 samples (~20 × 10-5 molecules Mn-1 s-1 on all three samples, Fig. 5b), about three-fold smaller for OMS-2 (6.8 ×10-5 molecules Mn-1 s-1) and much smaller for the other samples (0.5 × 10-5 Mn-1 s-1, 0.2 ×10-5 V-1 s-1, and 1.2 V-1 s-1, for OMS-7, V2O5, and MoVTeNbO, respectively). The lower reactivity of the latter three samples is also consistent with the lower BET surface areas. However, these differences in rates reflect contributions from pore volumes and surface areas, their accessibility, and the intrinsic reactivity of oxoanions bound to manganese versus vanadium cations. These intrinsic reactivity differences should essentially cancel when rate ratios of ethane and cyclohexane are considered because both molecules are activated by rate-limiting first C-H activation steps, and an oxo-anion that abstracts the H atom from C2H6 more effectively must be more effective for the H atom in cyclohexane [50]. Therefore, we examine the rate ratios next. Fig. 5c shows that the ethane to cyclohexane rate ratio is the smallest (0.5) for the V2O5 sample that was previously considered as a reference sample without significant micropore accessibility. [9] In contrast, the rate ratio is more than an order of magnitude larger in the MoVTeNbO sample (7.9), in which most ethane molecules react inside pores, but cyclohexane molecules are excluded from the pores. In addition, OMS-1, OMS-2, OMS-5, and OMS-6 samples exhibit intermediate rate ratios (1.2–2.62), suggesting that these samples provide at least somewhat selective access to the micropores for ethane molecules at locations inaccessible to cyclohexane. However, the rate ratio for the OMS-7 sample is even slightly higher (9.4) than the MoVTeNbO sample, suggesting that it exhibits highly selective access to the small ethane molecule. Fig. 5d shows these rate ratios as a function of the ratio of micropore volume to the external BET surface area of the oxides shown in Table 3. The rate ratio would be directly proportional to these area ratios for identical geometries with the same pore accessibility for a given molecule and van der Waals stabilization of molecules within pores. However, the pore geometries differ significantly among the oxides studied here. Taking the M1 phase MoVTeNb oxide as a reference with pores accessible to ethane and inaccessible to cyclohexane, Fig. 5d shows that V2O5 and OMS-2 samples lie close to but slightly below the dashed line connecting the origin to MoVTeNbO. This suggests that these oxides discriminate between ethane and cyclohexane to a similar extent, and V2O5 and OMS-2 samples have smaller relative quantities of pores, which leads to a smaller rate ratio. In contrast, OMS-1, OMS-5, and OMS-6 lie well below the dashed line, suggesting that these oxides are less discriminating between micropore active site accessibility between ethane and cyclohexane. This observation is consistent with the fact that the tunnels in these oxides are larger than the 4 Å and closer to the 6 Å size that allows accessibility to cyclohexane. The OMS-7 sample (commercial MnO2) lies well above the dashed line, suggesting that this oxide is highly selective in allowing access to active sites to ethane but excluding the cyclohexane. This result is surprising and counterintuitive because the OMS-7 pores are too small to allow access to even ethane (Table 3). We surmise that OMS-7 samples either possess native defects with missing rows of MnO2 units leading to larger pores occasional pores within the crystallites, or that these defects are formed during the high-temperature ethane oxidation reactions. To further probe this possibility, we probe pore accessibility and intrapore stabilization of ethane and cyclohexane in OMS crystals with and without pores using DFT calculations. 3.6 DFT calculations Fig. 6 shows DFT optimized geometries of ethane and cyclohexane molecules stabilized inside pores of OMS-1, OMS-2, OMS-5, and OMS-7 frameworks. The electronic energies for the adsorption of these molecules intrapore relative to empty pores and isolated gaseous molecules are shown in Table 4. OMS-1 contains large pores (sizes in Table 3) that easily accommodate both ethane and cyclohexane molecules (geometry in Fig. 6). These molecules are stabilized by van der Waals interactions with pore walls. As a result, both ethane and cyclohexane exhibit highly negative adsorption energies (−56 and −59 kJ mol-1, Table 4). Studies by Shen et al. showed significant uptake of cyclohexane in OMS-1[19], which is consistent with these adsorption energies. OMS-5 frameworks are also long in one dimension, although a bit tight in the other direction, leading weaker than OMS-1 but similarly negative adsorption energies for ethane and cyclohexane (−22 and −12 kJ mol-1, Table 4), which also suggests a weak discrimination between ethane and cyclohexane for accessibility to pores. In contrast to these larger pores, OMS-2 can only accommodate ethane, and the adsorption energy for this is positive, suggesting that the pores are much tighter (+64 kJ mol-1). For OMS-7, the pores are much smaller and cannot allow any molecules. However, upon defect creation as shown in Fig. 6f, g, both ethane, and cyclohexane are significantly stabilized in the pores of OMS-2 (ΔE = −66 and −112 kJ mol-1, respectively Table 4). In contrast, for OMS-7 after defect creation, as shown in Fig. 6i, ethane can be significantly stabilized (ΔE = −32 kJ mol-1), but cyclohexane could not be stabilized without transferring H-atoms to the pore walls. The formation energies for these defects are also not very large and are comparable to typical surface formation energies. For example, in OMS-7, the creation of a tunnel by removal of 6 MnO2 units form the DFT supercell, as shown in Fig. 6i, increases the energy of the immediate exposed tunnel MnO2 units by 37 kJ mol-1 per unit MnO2, assuming that the non-exposed interior MnO2 units have the same energy as the OMS-7 supercell without defects. Therefore, it is possible that the small amounts of micropores detected in OMS-7 originate from such tunnel defects that are highly selective to ethane activation over cyclohexane. The selectivities toward desired ODH product ethene in ethane oxidation reaction were analyzed, as shown in Fig. S5. The OMS materials exhibit much lower selectivities (< 10%) than the M1 phase MoVTeNbO samples as well as V2O5 samples. This suggests that Mn oxides in the OMS samples are significantly more prone to overoxidation than vanadium-containing oxides. Higher temperature studies on OMS (1073 K) show higher selectivity toward ethylene (93% selectivity at 80% conversion), but in the absence of O2 co-feed [51,52]. For vanadium-containing oxides, MoVTeNbO has higher selectivity (> 95%) than V2O5, and recent studies have proposed that pore confinement helps improve selectivity in MoVTeNbO [9,53]. However, even in the case of OMS samples, there is a weak trend with pore geometries, with OMS-2 and OMS-1 samples exhibiting slightly higher ethene selectivity than the larger pore size-discriminating samples. Thus, pore confinement can slightly influence selectivity, but weak intrinsic selectivity of Mn oxides leads to low selectivity despite the improvements. Such possible pore effects on selectivity need to be further probed for other reactions such as alcohol oxidation in which Mn oxides have better intrinsic selectivity. When compared to other catalysts in literature, manganese-containing materials (promoted or in the structure) showed higher conversions and selectivities than the OMS materials, MoVTeNbO, and V2O5 (Table S1). This is accomplished by using chemical looping and/or higher temperatures (up to 1123 K). This is consistent with the previous literature discussed above. Similar trends were observed for cyclohexane oxidation in Fig. S6. A plausible mechanism can be proposed using elementary steps using Mars van Krevelen oxidation-reduction proposed for oxide-based catalysts inspired by a previously reported mechanism (Scheme S1a) [3,9]. The adsorption of C2H6 on the lattice oxygen bonded to Mn in the first step (MnO*), followed by two sequential C-H activations (a surface hydroxyl species and •C2H5 radical in the second step and C2H4 and an additional surface OH species in step 3). Each C-H activation is coupled with a reduction of manganese (Mn4+ → Mn3+, then Mn3+ → Mn2+). These create two surface hydroxyl species. Next, the desorption of ethylene (C2H4) is followed by the combination and desorption of water (H2O). This also oxidizes the Mn2+ to Mn3+. Finally, the replenishment of lattice oxygens by oxygen from the feed serves to oxidize the Mn3+ to Mn4+. The ethylene can continuously go through this oxidation-reduction cycle to create further oxidation products. Scheme S1b shows the oxidation-reduction cycle for cyclohexane which follows similar steps to that of ethane. In addition to the factors affecting pore accessibility that were probed by DFT (Fig. 6 , Table 3), the trends can also be affected by uncertainties in micropore volumes due to hysteresis in CO2 uptakes. These factors will further increase the micropore volumes and will push OMS-1 and OMS-5 material below the trend for MoVTeNbO referenced in Fig. 5d. Another possible contributing factor is the changes in pore geometries at the reaction conditions. To probe these factors, samples after the C2H6 oxidation reaction were analyzed via CO2 sorption and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. The post-reaction CO2 sorption studies show a drop in OMS-1 micropore volume, possibly due to pore-blockage [54] or partial framework collapse, and a slight increase in OMS-2 pore volume, possibly reflecting defect creation [55] (Figs. S7 and S8 and Table S2 respectively). In post ethane reaction XPS studies on OMS-1 (Fig. S9 and Table S3), the adjusted peak position of Mn are at 642.2 ± 2 eV. In contrast, oxygen 1 s peaks show surface hydroxyl groups from molecular water (OOH+MW, 531 eV) and lattice oxygen (OL, 530 eV) [46]. The ratio OOH:OL increased from 1:1 to 3:1 in the post ethane sample. This is indicative of surfaces containing more molecular water and surface hydroxyl groups. In OMS-1, post cyclohexane reaction XPS spectra have an adjusted peak position for Mn at 641.8 ± 2 eV. After both reactions, the adjusted peak shifted to lower binding energies, possibly due to the partial reduction of the catalysts. In both cases, the oxidation state of manganese is still indicative of Mn 4+ [45]. In the O 1 s spectra, there is the presence of an additional peak, labeled OA corresponding to aliphatic C-OH (532.7 eV) [56], possibly due to the presence of adsorbed products and reactant species. In the case of OMS-2, the post ethane catalyst has an adjusted peak position of Mn at 642.7 ± 2 eV, and post cyclohexane has an adjusted peak position at 642.7 ± 2 eV (Fig. S10 and Table S4). Both of these spent catalysts show a minimal reduction in adjusted binding energies from the unused catalyst suggesting that the catalyst may be back to its initial state. In addition, the O 1 s spectra show a similar nature to that of OMS-1 analogs, suggesting the catalyst may have adsorbed species. OMS-5, the post ethane catalyst Mn spectrum, has an adjusted peak position at 642.3 ± 2 eV (Fig. S11 and Table S5). This shows a drop of 0.4 eV compared to the unused sample, indicating a slight reduction on the catalyst's surface. In addition, the O 1 s showed the presence of OA, indicating the presence of possible adsorbed species. When comparing the XPS data for the post-reaction ethane sample and the fresh sample, OMS-6, the post ethane catalyst, had an adjusted peak position at 642.5 ± 2 eV (Fig. S12 and Table S6), which indicates no change in surface oxidation state for manganese. In addition, the O 1 s showed a higher proportion of OA in the post-reaction sample, coupled with a decrease in the molecular water peak. Overall, it was observed that OMS-2 had the highest post ethane reaction Mn 2p3/2 peak position (642.7 ± 2 eV) among the OMS materials tested but had the least conversion and ODH rate (Fig. 5a). While all four OMS materials in the post-ethane XPS spectra showed adjusted peak positions are within the region for Mn4+, the presence of deconvoluted peaks in the range of 640.8–641.8 eV can be attributed to the presence of Mn3+ and/or Mn2+ [57]. When comparing the post ethane reaction samples for the OMS materials tested, the OMS-2 shows an increase in intensity for the peak at 614.2 eV, higher than other peaks in that area for the other samples (Normalized 29% in OMS-2, 20.6% in OMS-1, 26.5% in OMS-5% and 25.9% for OMS-6). The increased Mn3+ and/or Mn2+ amounts shown may be correlated to the decrease in ethane ODH rates due to the non-complete re-oxidation of manganese. Mn4+ has also been previously seen to be highly active for the complete oxidation of hydrocarbons [58,59]. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, manganese oxide-based OMS-1, OMS-2, OMS-5, and OMS-6 oxides with 3 × 3, 2 × 2, 2 × 4, and 2 × 3 tunnel structures, respectively, were prepared. OMS-7 was used as commercially available. These four materials were characterized using X-ray diffraction, scanning electron microscopy, transmission electron microscopy, and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, as well as N2 and CO2 sorption experiments. These materials were then utilized in the study of ethane and cyclohexane ODH. The differences in the ODH activity of the different samples for ethane versus cyclohexane can be explained by the higher rates occurring with increased pore size. For all OMS samples, ethane showed higher activity due to easier access of ethane, since for 4 OMS materials tested, the pore size is larger than that of ethane, while cyclohexane is either too large or fits tightly into the pore. The ethane to cyclohexane rate ratio directly correlates with pore size and the rate ratio. As the tunnel size increases, the rate ratios decreases, OMS-2 > OMS-1 > OMS-6 > OMS-5, indicating that cyclohexane activity increases with tunnel size. OMS-7 was seen as an outlier showing almost a 10-fold rate ratio, indicating ethane is highly selective over cyclohexane, which was unexpected, and is speculated to be related to the formation of tunnel defects that can selectively stabilize ethane. Combining the ODH rates with the DFT calculations, the reactions are occurring within the pores of the OMS materials, which may serve as active sites. The post characterization analysis shows a drop in CO2 adsorbed in the spent catalyst compared to the fresh catalyst, possibly due to substrate or products being adsorbed on the surface. Similar results were seen for the surface oxidation state analysis using XPS, that there is a shift to lower binding energies for all four OMS catalysts. The DFT adsorption energies, with the addition of tunnel defects for OMS-7 and OMS-2, the micropore adsorption energy follows a trend of OMS-5 > OMS-7 > OMS-1 > OMS-2 with ethane as an adsorbent. coredata.dc:description: Octahedral molecular sieve (OMS) materials classified by their different tunnel sizes are defined by edge-sharing MnO6 octahedra. Four different OMS materials (OMS-1, OMS-2, OMS-5, and OMS-6) are benchmarked for ethane (C2H6) and cyclohexane (C6H12) oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) and compared with commercial MnO2, M1 phase MoVTeNb oxide, and vanadium oxide (V2O5). The accessibility of the quadrilateral tunnels of the OMS materials to C2H6 and C6H12 were further evaluated using density functional theory (DFT). C2H6 and C6H12 ODH rates for the four OMS materials were higher than those measured for commercial MnO2, MoVTeNbO, and V2O5. The C2H6/C6H12 rate ratios on the four OMS oxides are larger than V2O5. Rate relations for selective accessibility for C2H6 in small pores, accessibility to both molecules in large pores, and the presence of tunnel defects are discussed. Product selectivities show slightly higher ethylene selectivity in smaller pores suggesting possible connections between pore confinement and selectivity.
coredata.dc:title: Assessment of micropore accessibility for hydrocarbon oxidation in manganese oxide sieves
